body:
https://patreon.com/ruqqus

Having hit $750/mo, the production server costs are covered! This includes:

* One dedicated monster server ($500/mo)
* One leader database for all write operations ($50/mo)
* One follower database for all read operations which gets updates from the leader streamed constantly ($200/mo)

This all includes automatic backups, auto failure detection and failover, clustering and auto failover for both databases, and reliable uptime.

At least, when I haven't crashed it.

Thank you everyone for your support!

body:
So, for $500/mo - I would think that the better route would be to use many VPS for application servers, with cheap-ish squid's in front of them?

Granted, this does result in more administrative overhead, but at some point, we (hopefully) run into more traffic than a single monolithic server can support.

Additionally, geographically (even inside the US) diverse application servers / user-facing proxies would be more fault tolerant, harder to take down, and probably faster.

It's possible that you could cut down on the administrative overhead by using something like puppet.

We probably aren't in a place yet where this is really needed however.

post.body:
https://patreon.com/ruqqus

Having hit $750/mo, the production server costs are covered! This includes:

* One dedicated monster server ($500/mo)
* One leader database for all write operations ($50/mo)
* One follower database for all read operations which gets updates from the leader streamed constantly ($200/mo)

This all includes automatic backups, auto failure detection and failover, clustering and auto failover for both databases, and reliable uptime.

At least, when I haven't crashed it.

Thank you everyone for your support!

body: Interesting. Have you considered changing platforms? I don't know what Heroku offers, but other cloud providers (I am proficient in AWS and Azure, so I will use them as examples) offer a lot of things that could cut costs. If you used microservices you could use something like Lambda or Azure functions for running the code, a caching layer with memcached, a managed db and S3 or blob storage for the media would fit into the current budget and assure that Ruqqus will be HA no matter what. Even now, you could use the same layout but instead of functions, you could use a VM or containers. I can hit you up on Discord if you're interested in something like that. I really enjoy Ruqqus and would like it to succeed.
body_html: Interesting. Have you considered changing platforms? I don't know what Heroku offers, but other cloud providers (I am proficient in AWS and Azure, so I will use them as examples) offer a lot of things that could cut costs. If you used microservices you could use something like Lambda or Azure functions for running the code, a caching layer with memcached, a managed db and S3 or blob storage for the media would fit into the current budget and assure that Ruqqus will be HA no matter what. Even now, you could use the same layout but instead of functions, you could use a VM or containers. I can hit you up on Discord if you're interested in something like that. I really enjoy Ruqqus and would like it to succeed.

post.body:
https://patreon.com/ruqqus

Having hit $750/mo, the production server costs are covered! This includes:

* One dedicated monster server ($500/mo)
* One leader database for all write operations ($50/mo)
* One follower database for all read operations which gets updates from the leader streamed constantly ($200/mo)

This all includes automatic backups, auto failure detection and failover, clustering and auto failover for both databases, and reliable uptime.

At least, when I haven't crashed it.

Thank you everyone for your support!

parent.body:
So, for $500/mo - I would think that the better route would be to use many VPS for application servers, with cheap-ish squid's in front of them?

Granted, this does result in more administrative overhead, but at some point, we (hopefully) run into more traffic than a single monolithic server can support.

Additionally, geographically (even inside the US) diverse application servers / user-facing proxies would be more fault tolerant, harder to take down, and probably faster.

It's possible that you could cut down on the administrative overhead by using something like puppet.

We probably aren't in a place yet where this is really needed however.
